title: Estimating Commonsense Plausibility through Semantic Shifts
author: Wanqing Cui (Chinese Academy of Sciences), Keping Bi (Chinese Academy of Sciences), Jiafeng Guo (Chinese Academy of Sciences), Xueqi Cheng (Chinese Academy of Sciences), ...
relevance_why: The proposed method ComPaSS could be applied to improve the commonsense reasoning capabilities in audio-based applications through better contextual understanding.
background: Commonsense plausibility estimation aims to measure whether sentences align with common human understanding of the world, crucial for tasks requiring nuanced language comprehension.
contribution: This paper introduces ComPaSS, a method that estimates commonsense plausibility by measuring semantic shifts when augmenting sentences with commonsense-related information, achieving improved performance on fine-grained tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily relied on generative approaches such as likelihood estimation and verbalized judgments, which struggled with fine-grained plausibility discrimination.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon prior methods by adopting a discriminative perspective, measuring semantic shifts rather than relying solely on generative outputs.

key_innovation: The unique aspect of ComPaSS is its ability to quantify plausibility through the minimal semantic shifts in sentence augmentations, enhancing commonsense reasoning capabilities.
real_world_impact: Enhancing language models' commonsense reasoning could lead to more realistic and controlled outputs in AI applications, such as dialogue systems and creative AI. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The method may struggle with making absolute plausibility judgments due to the inherent complexities in measuring semantic distances.

new_terms.semantic shifts: **Semantic shifts** refer to changes in meaning that occur when additional context or information is added to a statement, affecting its plausibility in a commonsense context.
